Under Section 51 of the Lisbon treaty, foreign nationals being held in Britain and extraditable in the US are usually placed on trial in the European Court of Human Rights. Although the US has allowed some foreign nationals extradited since the 1980s to appeal their conviction, a ban on foreigners being prosecuted in the European Court of Human Rights makes Article 51 of the treaty apply.

A US magistrate in Lisbon said in a press conference on Wednesday he would be examining two motions submitted to a panel of judges with jurisdiction to make Article 53 of the treaty.

The motions are:

a foreign national being held as an adult within the European Convention (and in some cases extradited to the US in person);

an appeal from the extradition of an adult foreign national; and

a new extradition order.
